title: Pitino promises answers in emotional speech
text:
Activate your digital access. Pitino promises answers in emotional speech Louisville basketball coach Rick Pitino took time to address the recent paid escort allegations made by Katina Powell in her new book "Breaking Cardinal Rules" during Cards annual luncheon event. Alton Strupp/The Courier-Journal Jeff Greer , @jeffgreer_cj 9:52 p.m. EDT October 13, 2015 Buy Photo U of L basketball coach Rick Pitino waves to the audience following his speech during the annual U of L Tip-off Luncheon event at the downtown Louisville Marriott. Oct. 13, 2015 (Photo: Alton Strupp/The Courier-Journal) Buy Photo 9 CONNECT 17 TWEET LINKEDIN 1 COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
Rick Pitino walked up to the podium at the downtown Marriott on Tuesday afternoon and said the NCAA suggested he doesn't speak about the ongoing internal and NCAA investigations into allegations against his program that were laid out in a new book. 
But the Louisville basketball coach couldn't resist the chance to speak directly to the roughly 1,200 U of L fans at the annual Basketball Tipoff Luncheon, and he delivered a nearly 19-minute speech that, after a brief opener about his 2015-16 Cardinals, focused almost entirely on controversy surrounding U of L hoops. 
In his wide-ranging talk, Pitino blasted Sports Illustrated – "I don't care what Sports Illustrated says. I haven't read them in years" – for a recent column claiming U of L has nurtured a dangerous culture toward women. He said he was "blindsided" by radio host Terry Meiners in an interview last week, during which Meiners, a friend of Pitino's, asked the coach if he intended to resign. Get the CJ’s free UofL CardsHQ newsletter 
Pitino saved his more emotional, pointed words for the book, titled "Breaking Cardinal Rules: Basketball and the Escort Queen," that claims former U of L staffer Andre McGee paid thousands of dollars and gave game tickets to escorts in exchange for dancing for and having sex with players and recruits. 
"When this came out, it hit us all like a bombshell," Pitino said. "I just don't understand why. There's a lot of ifs here – if it did happen. And the ifs are not being answered, and they have to be answered by the NCAA. 
"I'm not allowed to talk to any players about it. I'm not allowed to do any investigating on my own, which is fine by me. But I do know this: If there was any wrongdoing – that's a big 'if' – then people have to pay for their crimes. And that's an 'if.' If it happens, we will own up to it and do the best we can under adverse situations." U of L luncheon | Pitino delves into scandal 
U of L's Hall of Fame coach did weave some thoughts on his current team throughout his words, saying it could be the best shot-blocking team he has had. But, he said, he admitted to them in practice that he was down about the fallout from the book's allegations. 
David Ridpath, an expert in compliance and NCAA enforcement issues who is a professor at Ohio University, said last week that one of the most difficult parts about investigations is that they "hang over your head," because they require such an exhaustive, comprehensive amount of research. 
After the team's first Red-White intrasquad scrimmage two Saturdays ago, Pitino said he would channel his focus, emotion and time into basketball, though he has acknowledged several times in the past 10 days that he has had trouble sleeping. 
On Tuesday, Pitino said he told his players that they "lift me up, because I've never had a group like this in my life." In raving about the team's chemistry and character, something he has done since May, Pitino pulled out his phone to read a text message from one of the team's leaders. 
"He said, 'The enemy comes to kill, steal and destroy,'" Pitino began. "'We have something very special on our horizon, and this attack on our program is just verification. The Bible says that no weapon formed against you shall prosper, but it never said that it wouldn't form. I serve a God who can use our problems to bring glory to his name. Have no fear, Coach. I love you.'" Transcript: Pitino's Tipoff Luncheon speech 
The crowd roared with an extended applause. Pitino cracked a joke. Then he closed with a flourish, expressing his gratitude to his friends and family and the U of L fan base's support. 
"We'll get through this the right way, and whatever sits upon us, we will find out with the right people investigating," he said. "We won't go by hearsay. I know what this program is all about. I feel very, very confident in what the players are all about. And this group that you're going to see on Saturday (in a second preseason scrimmage), you're going to see something really special. I think we can go very far. 
"They will do great things on the basketball court, and they'll represent you exactly the way you'd want of a Louisville basketball player." 
Follow U of L hoops writer Jeff Greer on Twitter ( @jeffgreer_cj ) for regular Cards updates.
